conclusion: The p-V diagram shows three states (A, B, and C) of an ideal gas connected by vertical and horizontal lines.
From the diagram, the pressure remains constant at 2 × 10³ Pa while the volume increases from 2 × 10⁻³ m³ to 3 × 10⁻³ m³.

premise: The pressure remains constant at 2 × 10³ Pa while the volume increases from 2 × 10⁻³ m³ to 3 × 10⁻³ m³.
conclusion: This is an isobaric (constant pressure) process.
For a constant pressure process, work done by the gas is: W = p ⋅ (V_f - V_i), where p is the constant pressure, V_f is the final volume, and V_i is the initial volume.
Pressure p = 2 × 10³ Pa, Initial volume V_i = 2 × 10⁻³ m³ (at point B), Final volume V_f = 3 × 10⁻³ m³ (at point C).

premise: Pressure p = 2 × 10³ Pa, Initial volume V_i = 2 × 10⁻³ m³, Final volume V_f = 3 × 10⁻³ m³.
conclusion: Substitute the values into the formula: W = 2 × 10³ Pa × (3 × 10⁻³ m³ - 2 × 10⁻³ m³).
Calculate the work done: W = 2 × 10³ Pa × 1 × 10⁻³ m³ = 2 × 10³ × 1 × 10⁻³ J = 2 J.

premise: The positive sign of the work indicates that the gas does work on the surroundings as it expands from state B to state C at constant pressure.
conclusion: The work done externally by the gas during the process from state B to state C is 2 joules.
